title: 103_hr1829
content: The Act may be cited as the "Women's Violence-Related Injury Reduction Act". The Congress acknowledges the serious threats of domestic violence and sexual assault to women's health and well-being in the United States. These forms of violence lead to severe physical and mental health consequences, affecting millions of women annually. Approximately 4,000,000 women are victims of domestic violence each year, with one in two women experiencing violence in their lifetime. Battering is identified as the primary cause of injury to women, and even pregnant women are not spared from the risk, with an estimated one in six facing violence. Domestic violence against pregnant women leads to increased rates of miscarriage, stillbirths, and low-birthweight babies. It accounts for a significant number of emergency room visits, hospitalizations, and visits to physicians annually. Medical personnel often fail to correctly diagnose victims of domestic violence, and there is a lack of uniform protocols in hospitals and clinics for identifying and referring these victims. A national surveillance system should be established to monitor the health effects of domestic violence and sexual assault in the United States. Establishment of health programs regarding domestic violence and sexual assault under Part B of title III of the Public Health Service Act. The Secretary may grant funds for demonstration projects to identify and refer victims of domestic violence and sexual assault to relevant services. The Secretary may authorize grants for training health care providers in community organizations to identify and refer victims of domestic violence and sexual assault. Grants may also be used to develop protocols for this purpose. The Secretary may authorize grants for training health care providers and public education on domestic violence and sexual assault. Applicants must consult with relevant entities and submit reports for grant consideration. The Secretary authorizes grants for training health care providers and public education on domestic violence and sexual assault. The Secretary also conducts epidemiological research on domestic violence and sexual assault to collect data on incidence, costs of health care, injuries sustained, and victims seeking treatment. The Secretary conducts research on domestic violence and sexual assault, including comparing case incidence with treatment seeking, describing factors influencing victims not seeking treatment, types of facilities victims seek treatment from, and demographic characteristics of individuals in the data collection. The Secretary cooperates with states to establish a national data collection system for domestic violence and sexual assault, ensuring confidentiality standards are maintained. The Secretary conducts research on domestic violence and sexual assault, including data collection and reporting to Congress every two years. $20,000,000 is authorized for fiscal year 1994, with additional funding for 1995-1997. The Secretary must allocate at least 60 percent of the appropriated amounts for grants under subsection (a).
